questions.question: Which of the following is a risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma? Epstein-Barr (EB) virus Dry salted fish Chinese population Cigarette smoking Opium smoking Inhalation of smoke from Incense
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All the above Explanation: All of the listed factors can increase the risk of nasopharyngeal carcinoma Etiology: Genetic Higher susceptibility in the Chinese population (Option D) Viral Epstein-Barr (EB) virus (Option D) Environmental (Option D) Air pollution Smoking (tobacco, opium) Nitrosamines from dry salted fish Inhalation of smoke from Incense Clinical features: Nasal Obstruction Discharge Denasal speech (rhinolalia clausa) Epistaxis Otologic Conductive hearing loss Serous or suppurative otitis media (Unilateral serous otitis media in adults is an important indicator) Tinnitus Dizziness due to Eustachian tube obstruction Ophthalmoneurologic Squint Diplopia (CN VI involvement) Ophthalmoplegia (CN III, IV, VI) Facial pain Reduced corneal reflex (CN V involvement) Exophthalmos Blindness (CN II) Jugular foramen syndrome with CN IX, X, and XI involvement Horner syndrome Cervical Nodal Metastases Lump of nodes between the angle of the jaw and mastoid, or along the spinal accessory in the posterior triangle Distant Metastases Common sites-bone, lung, and liver Common symptoms Cervical lymphadenopathy Hearing loss Nasal obstruction Epistaxis Cranial nerve palsies (CN VI most common) Headache Earache Neck pain Weight loss Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition, Page 296-298

questions.question: A 58-year-old man presents with persistent nasal obstruction and bloody nasal discharge over the past 3 months. On examination, he has unilateral conductive hearing loss and a swelling in his neck. Imaging studies reveal a nasopharyngeal mass with cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of these symptoms is a part of the Trotter's triad?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Conductive hearing loss Explanation: Trotter's triad - Triad of these 3 symptoms in nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Conductive hearing loss due to blockage of the eustachian tube Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia from the involvement of cranial nerve V Palatal paralysis resulting from involvement of cranial nerve X Diagnosis of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma: Endoscopy Biopsy is taken Imaging CT Scan/MRI of Nasopharynx and Neck - High-resolution, contrast-enhanced CT is the preferred method MRI of Nasopharynx and Neck - better for assessing soft-tissue extension and lymph nodes Positron Emission Tomography (PET) - for detecting metastases throughout the body Screening Epstein-Barr viral markers Audiogram Diagnosing of serous otitis media Monitors for side effects of radiation and chemotherapy Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 297,298

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. On examination, he has a large nasopharyngeal mass with invasion into the surrounding bony structures and involvement of the intracranial space. Imaging studies reveal multiple lymph nodes in the neck, some of which are greater than 6 cm in size. There is no evidence of distant metastasis . What is the TNM staging of this cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) T4N3aM0 Explanation: TNM staging of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Category Stage Description Primary Tumour (T) T1 Tumour confined to the nasopharynx T2 Tumour extends to soft tissues of the oropharynx and/or nasal cavity T3 Tumour invades bony structures and/or paranasal sinuses T4 Tumour with intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx, orbit, or masticator space Regional Lymph Nodes (N) Nx Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed N0 No regional lymph node metastasis N1 Unilateral metastasis in lymph node(s), ≤ 6 cm in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa N2 Bilateral metastasis in lymph nodes, ≤ 6 cm in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa N3a Metastasis greater than 6 cm in lymph node(s) N3b Metastasis in lymph node(s) in the supraclavicular fossa Distant Metastasis (M) MX Distant metastasis cannot be assessed M0 No distant metastasis M1 Distant metastasis Treatment of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Stages I and II: radiotherapy Stages III and IV: Concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy Recurrent cases: IMRT (Intensity-Modulated Radiation Therapy) Depending on stage. Also surgery is the treatment in recurrence. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition, Pages 298-299

questions.question: Which of the following is the common symptom of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Epistaxis Explanation Profuse, recurrent nosebleeds (epistaxis) are the hallmark symptom of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA0 and are often the first presenting sign due to the fragile, thin-walled vessels in the tumor. JNA - Clinical Features Nasal and Nasopharyngeal Symptoms Epistaxis: Recurrent , profuse nosebleeds due to fragile, thin-walled vessels. (Option B) Nasal Obstruction: Progressive blockage causing nasal voice. Nasal Discharge: Often from secondary sinusitis or obstruction. (Option D ruled out) Otologic Symptoms Conductive Hearing Loss: Eustachian tube obstruction leading to fluid in the middle ear. (Option C ruled out) Otitis Media with Effusion: Fluid build-up, possible ear pain. Ophthalmo-neurological Symptoms Proptosis: Eyeball protrusion from orbital invasion. Diplopia: Double vision due to cranial nerve compression (CN III, IV, VI). (Option A ruled out) Cranial Nerve Palsies: Various deficits like vision changes (CN II), facial pain (CN V), or swallowing difficulty (CN IX, X). Facial Deformity Broadening of Nasal Bridge: Widening from tumor pressure. Cheek Swelling: Asymmetry due to tumor extension. Frog-Face Deformity: Bilateral proptosis with bulging eyes and flattened profile. Other Features Age and Sex: Predominantly affects adolescent males (10-20 years) . Rare in females or older individuals. Endoscopic Appearance: Smooth or lobulated reddish-purple mass blocking nasal passages. Consistency: Firm but should not be palpated due to bleeding risk.

questions.question: A 17-year-old male presents with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and a reddish-purple mass visible in the nasal cavity. He also reports occasional facial pain. CECT scan finding is shown below. Which investigation is most useful in evaluating the vascularity of this tumor and planning for preoperative embolization?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Digital Subtraction Angiography Explanation Case scenario suggests JNA and CECT shows a mass in the nasopharynx with anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Holman-Miller sign). Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is the best imaging modality to evaluate the vascularity of the tumor and to identify feeding vessels for preoperative embolization, which helps reduce intraoperative blood loss. JNA is a highly vascular tumor, primarily supplied by the internal maxillary artery , a branch of the external carotid artery. Larger lesions may involve multiple feeding arteries.The second most common source is the ascending pharyngeal artery . Examination of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)
